Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Otago No, it is not about money. There is a huge debate as to whether any PSA testing should be done, let alone many years younger. I don't recall reading why you had your psa taken at age 38, but I don't know of anyone suggesting those under age 40 get the test. Actually its not only about the cost of testing, but more about the cost of treating so many people who probably don't need treating. Indolent cases. The entire field of testing and treating is a mess that won't be solved until they develop some method of knowing which cases need treatment and which don't. The first company to figure that out will make billions. I only had it checked because I hard time peeing. Went to a Uro to get checked out, DRE showed some "firmness". He ordered a PSA test and that led to a biopsy. I am just thankful to have caught it when I did and to have had some kind of symptom. If I had waited, we would be having a very different conversation.
Posts.Signature: 38 y/o Initial PSA of 11.8 on 5/15 Retest of PSA 9.8 on 6/17 Biopsy on 7/3 12 of 12 cores positive, Gleason 3+4 with some cores showing 4+3 CT scan negative Bone scan negative Surgery scheduled with Dr. William Catalona, Northwestern University Chicago 8/13/13 Post surgery path report showed tumor went outside prostate on one side, seminal vesticles involved on one side. Lymph nodes showed no involvement Upgraded to 4+3 Gleason
Posts.Title: Why so little publicity for Prostate Cancer?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Otago Its mostly about money. Many companies have tied into the pink ribbon breast cancer awareness ONLY as a method to market their products to women between the ages of 25 and 65. Just Google (pink ribbon companies) and a few other terms to see how the marketing has progressed. Also, the fact that women are more open to discuss the issue combined with the fact that breast cancer is less curable than prostate cancer. Additionally, there are about 40,000 women who die while "only" 30,000 men die. More important, many of the women who die are fairly young, while most men who die are past age 60 and don't create the impact or shock. Lots of reasons for the differences. If you ask about prostate cancer, many think of it as the good cancer which causes few deaths. In other words, everyone gets it and we still see them walking around, living a long life. (except for those who don't) All good and valid points, but I am still left with the feeling that we are marginalized. In my situation, if I had waited another few years, I would have probably been handed a death sentence, as it is I am still not in the clear. I can't help but wonder how much better off I would have been if I had found out this all out a few years ago. I fully understand that a man my age with Pca is very rare, but still why don't they do PSA checks a little younger? (I know the answer to that is money).

Posts.Content: This is an update to my last thread: See below for those interested. http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...t-good-numbers After meeting with several surgeons I have decided to go with Dr. William Catalona at Northwestern in Chicago. From what I can tell he is very well regarded and has over 6000 open procedures under his belt. I know lots of people go the Da Vinci route and that's fine, but for me and my cancer I feel that an open is a better choice. After meeting with him, my wife and I felt very confident that he will do all he can to not only cure me, but to preserve as much function as possible. He did make sure that I understood everything, including the possibility that my nerves will not be able to be able to be spared, but he said he will do all he can. This was leaps and bounds a better attitude than what I had from the last guy. So as it stands today, I will be going in on August 13th (I do need to get an MRI first, so that could push me back a day or two). All in all I am actually looking forward to it. I want this out of my body and I want to move forward. The last couple months have just been an emotional roller coaster for me and my family. at this point I just want to focus on getting better and moving forward. I cannot thank the people here enough. This site has really been a huge help to me, both in information and to just know that there are others out that can relate. More to follow. JD

Posts.Title: First time with Bimix.(warning mildly graphic,un politically correct, funny,long)

Posts.Content: Mods, if this is out of line please feel free to delete it. It is not my intention to offend anyone or anything like that. Sometimes a little humor helps. Alright, I've been deciding on whether or not I should post about this for several days. I understand some of you might not share my sense of humor about these kinds of things, but I have a feeling that most will . I want to share this because I think it might help some here and it is a funny story IMO. What I am about to share is 100% how it happened, I am not making this up, I probably couldn't if I tried. For those that might not know what Bimix is, I'll give a quick run down. It is a mix of two drugs that you self inject into the side your penis to give an erection. I know it sounds like the worst thing in the world to do this to yourself, but i can assure everyone that it is not as bad as it sounds and the results are OUTSTANDING! (for me at least). So here I am on a Friday, one month to the day after my open prostate surgery. My Dr. wanted to see me for a checkup, PSA test and to show me how to start with the Bimix injections. He wanted to make sure I knew how to inject and that I didn't have any reactions to the medicine. I went into the exam room with a pretty high degree of apprehension, I mean who really WANTS to stick a needle in the side of their penis. The nurse came in and did the routine stuff, drew some blood and left, saying the Dr. would see me in a few minutes. She assured me that it was not going to be as bad as I was making it out to be. So as I sat there and waited my mind was racing with the reality of what I was about to do. I've never been afraid of needles and after all the blood tests that one has to go through with my current situation, I am certainly getting used to it. But this was different. Sticking a needle in your penis is just not he same as your arm. After a bit the Dr. came in, asked me the usual questions, looked at my incision and deemed that I was healing up nicely. Then he said it was time for the injection He had me half leaning, half sitting on the exam table and asked me to drop my pants. Anyone who has been down the PCa road knows that humility and modesty are one the first things to go, I'll pretty much drop my pants anytime, anywhere for just about anyone these days (come to think of it, that's not much different than my pre-PCa days). So there I am in all my glory. The Dr. grabs the end of my penis and tells me "you want to stretch it out as far as it will go, like this" and proceeds to pin it to my upper thigh. At this point he has the injection in his other hand and shows me where and how to do it. Looking down I was in complete disbelief about what I was about to do. I was a shaking a little, but I just did it. After a small bit of resistance it went right in! I was shocked that I felt almost nothing, it honestly felt like a mosquito bite. I was like "that's it?" he told me that like most things in this journey the anticipation of the event is much worse than the reality, and I have to agree. Next he tells me to "massage the medication into my penis" at which point I raised one eyebrow and said jokingly "so you want me to jerk off...in your exam room?" Now my Dr. has no sense of humor at all and just responds with a stern look and says "I'll be back to check on you in about 10 minutes". So much fro trying to lighten the mood. I get it though, this guys spends his whole life looking at dudes schlongs and sticking his fingers in peoples rear ends, I don't blame him for being a little disconnected to it all. There I am "massaging" the medication. After a few minutes, low and behold my shriveled member starts to show signs of life again. This was a pretty emotional moment for me, I am only 38 and I hope to have a long and healthy sex life, so it was reassuring to see that things might work out after all. After about ten minutes the Dr. comes back in and asks "so anything happening?" my reply was to proudly put my hands on my hips and say "judge for yourself Doc!" He almost cracked a smile and told me "good thing I only gave you half a dose, otherwise you probably would have needed to go to the ER". He explained to me that if it lasts more than two hours to take a Sudafed (apparently it is an anti-boner medicine) and it that deos not work and if it lasts four hours to head right to the ER and tell them what's going on. This does not sound like a good time to me, so now I'm praying for this erection to go away. Its at this point that things get really funny. He tells me OK youre done for today and sends me on my merry way. There I am, in running pants (poor choice on my part), in a huge crowded hospital in the middle of downtown Chicago, with something in my pants that I really have no control over and that is pretty obvious. I felt like I was back in the 7th grade and had to stand up in front of the class to do a math problem on the blackboard. I walk out of his office and get on on an elevatorof course it is packed with people, Im taking asses to elbows packed. There is no option of waiting for a less crowded one as they are ALL like this. Im on the 21st floor and we all squeeze in. Im doing all I can to hide what it is going on but of course I think everyone can see it. As we start descending the car stops at about the 15th floor, Im hoping some people get out, but nooooo more people cram into this thing. And here is where it gets good, this could only happen to me. A little person (or what ever the PC term for a vertically challenged adult is these days) gets on and OF COURSE she stands right in front of me! Im thinking please dont turn around, please dont turn around as I am trying even harder not to poke her in the back of the head with my uncontrollable situation. Thankfully she got out a few floors later and I was able to relax just a bit. Being that it was now 1:30 and I had not eaten since 7:00am, I was starving so I grabbed a bit to eat at one of the food court places in the hospital and of course I run into one of my long time customers. In such a huge city, what are the chances. I've know this guy for a long time and coached him at ski camps that I run for years. Thankfully he did not notice anything (if he did he didn't let on). After that things were pretty calm. I got in my car for the drive home, the whole time hoping this thing would go away. At times I would think it was going away, only to find that it was not. I stopped at the drug store for some Sudafed, took one and went home and feel asleep for a few hours. When I woke up things were back to normal and I had to wonder if it was all just a really crazy dreamof course it was as real as the day is long. I have to say, on paper a 2 hour erection sounds like it might be fun, I can assure you its not. There is a reason those things only last a short time. So thats how my weekend started.
Posts.Signature: 38 y/o Initial PSA of 11.8 on 5/15 Retest of PSA 9.8 on 6/17 Biopsy on 7/3 12 of 12 cores positive, Gleason 3+4 with some cores showing 4+3 CT scan negative Bone scan negative Surgery scheduled with Dr. William Catalona, Northwestern University Chicago 8/13/13 Post surgery path report showed tumor went outside prostate on one side, seminal vesticles involved on one side. Lymph nodes showed no involvement Upgraded to 4+3 Gleason

Posts.Title: First time with Bimix.(warning mildly graphic,un politically correct, funny,long)

Posts.Content: Being newly diagnosed and having to tell my friends, family and co-workers I can understand, to make matters worse I just started a new, great job 2 months ago. My family has been great, my wife's sisters have been great. Friends, the couple true close friends that I have are great, they know me well enough to understand how my twisted brain and sense of humor works. Those friends who are not so close have pulled away a little bit. Most of this I feel is due to my age. Being only 38 and having friends of similar age, it's really hard for them to understand. Most of them have never had to deal with something like this, so I try to cut them some slack. Co-workers that I have told (pretty much 6-8 people in my dept) have been OK, they kinda just pretend nothing is wrong, but then again I don't really know these people yet. I think, as was mentioned before, that most people just don't know what to say. For many the word "cancer" conjurers up images of chemo patents and they think you are going to die. Men as a rule are very hesitant to talk to each other about health issues, so it's of no real surprise to me that people act a little "funny". For me, I am on a mission to get at least my small group of friends and family to start getting at least a PSA done early. If I had not had an issue with urinating and got a PSA test done, I would not have had a chance.

Posts.Title: A replacement word for cancer

Posts.Content: For those of you considering the injection route, do yourself a favor and don't wear running pants, wind pants or sweat pants of any kind to that appointment. Maybe a pair of tight cycling shorts under whatever pants you choose is a good idea. And the injection is not that bad at all, the needle is so small that it's almost hard to see.

Posts.Title: NCCN Guidelines for Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: I hear ya on the Cath part, I hated every second of it in. The day they they removed it (10 days post op), I felt 100 times better. I am 24 days post op and using 3-4 pads per day. I went back to work after 21 days. I don't leak to bad until I get up from my desk or move or reach funny. I think it's getting better little by little. I had a little jump in progress after the first two days and now progress has sort of leveled off. Best wishes on a speedy recovery. JD

Posts.Title: 9 days post-op

Posts.Content: Hi Highlander, My PSA's were 11.8 on the first test (blood was taken after a DRE, which I later found out to be poor procedure). So I had a second one done and it came out at 9.9. I'm off to get the bone scan done in the morning and then later in the week I'll get the CT done. Then I should have more details. In the mean time I've been talking to a few friends of friends who gone down this road and asked them about their surgeons, if the had good results etc. It's a starting point at least for me figure out who I might want to work on me. Thanks everyone for the support.

Posts.Title: Path report is in, not good numbers

Posts.Content: I just got back from my Uro and were given the results of my pathology report. 12 of 12 cores positive, Gleason 3+4. Most core percentages were in the 70's two in the 80's and a couple in the high 50-60's. Scheduling CT scan for later in the week to see if it has metastasized. Not he news I was hoping for, but it's my reality right now. All I can do is deal with it I suppose.

Posts.Title: Kids after prostate removal?

Posts.Content: Hello everyone. Can't say that I'm happy to be here, but I am happy there is a site like this. I am 38 years old, pretty healthy, not overweight and had my first PSA test done May 15 along with a DRE. I went to see the Urologist because of difficulty urinating. PSA was 11.9 and Dr said he felt firmness on one side of the prostate. We decided a second PSA might be a good idea so after 3 weeks I had a second one done, this time PSA was 9.9 Scheduled a biopsy, which was done last Wednesday (7/3/13), still waiting on the results form that. I have pretty much accepted that with THAT high of a PSA, along with firmness of the prostate, that I have very high chance of PC. Unfortunately, I don't really get the warm fuzzy feeling with my Urologist, he is very distant and almost hesitant to answer my questions. He's an older guy, maybe late 60's and seems very set in his ways. I picked him because he was in my network and is close to home. If this turns out to be something, I will be searching for a Dr I feel more comfortable with, but in the meantime, I'll stick with him. At my age, it sounds like surgery will be the most likely recommendation, but I'm not convinced it will be the best. I do have two young children and am married. What I have trouble finding is info about men with PC at my age. I really don't have anyone I can talk to about this that can relate, my friends are all my age or younger and have never had to deal with anything like this. So for now, I guess I don't have any real questions, just need a place where i can talk a little and get advice. So any advise is appreciated. Also, if anyone is in the Chicago area and has reccomdations for good Dr's please let me know. Thanks JD
Posts.Title: 38 years old, high PSA

Posts.Content: Well, not good news. I heard from my Uro yesterday afternoon and I do have Pca. Unfortunately he is not open on Fridays, so I will have to wait until Monday to see him and get the pathology report. So right now, I'm just kinda left hanging. I know that I should not assume the worst but it's kinda hard not to. More to come.
Posts.Title: 38 years old, high PSA

Posts.Title: Catheter is Out!

Posts.Content: My urologist did a 12 core biopsy in office. My issues started last fall and being a young, dumb guy, I figured it would just go away, well it didn't and it got a little worse so I went to see the Dr. I just figured that with a PSA that high, it would most likely not be caused by an "itis". I hope that is all it is, but in the mean time I am trying to learn as much as I can (which may or may not be a good thing). Through all of it I am trying to at least keep a sense of humor. I had a bit of fun grossing out all my younger friends with my horror stories of my latest Dr visits this past weekend. Whatever happens I am bound and determined to do whatever it takes, I'll be damned if I am going to let something like this keep me from seeing my kids grow up.
Posts.Title: 38 years old, high PSA

Posts.Content: Thanks fortyone, I read your link and I can only say that I hope mine goes as well. On the one hand we do have our age in our favor. I'm sure I have the same fears as everyone else. Monday will at least tell me more details and I'll be able to post up my numbers and then decide what I'm going to do. My gut is telling me surgery, but then I am on the hunt to find the best Dr. to do it. I'll just have to treat it like I do my hobbies, meaning, I tend to jump in with both feet and learn all I can about a subject.

Posts.Title: Shorter penis after prostate removal?

Posts.Content: Ski season is almost here. However due to my surgery and dealing with all the BS, this has been the active summer I have ever had and I am in terrible shape for the up coming season. I am nearing 8 weeks post OP, at 90% continence, 1 pad a day and almost never leak (a tiny bit if I lift something with a full bladder). My surgeon has lifted the weight limit, but I am still a little nervous about lifting anything heavy and setting my self back. I plan on being on snow starting early December. I am a life long ski racer and have worked in the ski industry for almost 20 years. Not skiing is simply not an option. So for those who have been down this road before me, how hard can I start working out. Should I stay off the bike? How about running? I understand that everyone heals different, I'm just looking for some general experiences.

Posts.Title: How long before I can start working out/bike riding etc.

Posts.Content: Thanks WJ. I understand that I can't just hit it hard like I usually do. Thankfully the races I do are on small hills now, my days of doing big mountain Super G and Downhills have been behind me for years, it's just SL and GS now. I'm thinking of doing a little light running and then starting in with some easy dry land stuff and weights. My main concern is the incision. It's healed, but so much of my training has always centered around the core that I am scared of a hernia or something. I guess the best thing is just to start slow and see how it goes. I think I will lay off the bike for awhile though.
